Award.AwardTitle: Exploring A Novel Buckling Mitigation Technique for Thin-Walled Steel Structures Using Pultruded FRP Sections

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of the research is to explore a new strengthening approach for thin-walled steel structures in which pultruded fiber reinforced polymer sections are bonded to vulnerable slender plates to inhibit local buckling failure modes. The approach relies on the out-of-plane flexural rigidity of the pultruded section to reduce the slenderness of thin steel plates. It is proposed to test about 27 monotonically loaded and 12 cyclically loaded specimens to validate the effectiveness of the new approach. The experimental program will study the effects of design parameters such as contact area, properties of epoxy, initial plate slenderness, and thermal conditions on the strength gains achievable using the new technique. Modeling approaches that can capture the de-bonding between the strengthened plate and the strengthening fiber reinforced polymer section will be developed. Epoxy degeneration models will be developed and used to establish a methodology for predicting strength gains, and to develop simplified design tools for engineers.

This research introduces a new concept of utilizing the out-of-plane stiffness of fiber reinforced polymer composite materials for structural strengthening of steel structures. If successful, this research will allow strengthening of deficient thin-walled steel structures using inexpensive, fast, and easy-to-apply pultruded sections without introducing adverse stress concentrations that are caused by usual welding of steel stiffeners. The outcome of this research would especially help in strengthening the deteriorating thin-walled bridge components to enhance their structural performance. One Ph.D. student with preference given to highly qualified students from underrepresented groups will be recruited from established institutional partnerships. Undergraduate engineering students will be involved in the experimental portion of the project and will assist in developing demonstration materials for open-day activities and high-school recruitment visits. The results will be widely disseminated through international conferences, journal publications, continuing education workshops, and an interactive web site that summarizes the major research findings.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aging infrastucture systems, such as schools, hospitals, and bridges, are in bad need for upgrading. Fully replacing them is not an option in most cases because of the associated costs. That's why rehabilitation and strengthening have gained a lot of attention over the last few decades.

Methods and techniques for strengthening steel structures typically involve welding or bolting additional steel plates to enhance their structural strength. While these techniques are effective, they lead to stress concentration and require highly skilled labor for their application. They are also time consuming, which can lead to long down times that facility users cannot afford. That's why the use of composite materials such as Fiber Reinforced Polymers (FRP) has increased because of their advantages such as high strength, light weight, and low resistance to corrosion.

This research explored the use of a cheaper FRP material alternative for strengthening of steel structures. Most strengthening applications involving FRP typically rely on Carbon FRP, or CFRP, whose high strength and modulus make it suitable for strengthening materials such as concrete and steel. Glass FRP, or GFRP, on the other hand has lower strength and modulus, but is cheaper. Therefore, it was always bypassed by most researchers for the better performing CFRP, until now. This research showed that pultruded GFRP stiffeners can be glued to steel structures like a cast to a fractured bone until it heals. The result is a new structure with higher resistance especially in bukcling prone areas where the plates are thin for optimization purposes. We also discovered that some adhesives are better suited for the proposed way of strengthening steel structures becuase their behavior is ductile as opposed to breaking in a brittle manner. We called the proposed method Strengthening-By-Stiffening or (SBS), which is a transforming in the sense that it allows the use of of cheaper materials (GFRP) as opposed to the commonly used more expensive alternative. 

This project facilitated the principal investigator's (PI) career delopment by supporting his research, funding his students and assisting in disseminating research findings in national and international conferences. More importantly, it enabled the training of one PhD student, one MS student and two undergraduate students. It should be noted that the two undraduate students (including one female) are now pursuing graduate degrees in engineerings.


Last Modified: 11/02/2015

This research explored the use of a cheaper FRP material alternative for strengthening of steel structures. Most strengthening applications involving FRP typically rely on Carbon FRP, or CFRP, whose high strength and modulus make it suitable for strengthening materials such as concrete and steel. Glass FRP, or GFRP, on the other hand has lower strength and modulus, but is cheaper. Therefore, it was always bypassed by most researchers for the better performing CFRP, until now.
